title: Sony confirms PlayStation 5 launching in 2020: What we know
text:
CLOSE

Video gamers await the latest from Sony. (Photo: Charly Triballeau, AFP/Getty Images)

The long-rumored arrival of Sony's next PlayStation has officially been confirmed.

Tuesday, Sony revealed its next video game console, PlayStation 5, will launch during the holiday 2020 season.

"These updates may not be a huge surprise, but we wanted to confirm them for our PlayStation fans, as we start to reveal additional details about our vision for the next generation," Sony Interactive Entertainment President and CEO Jim Ryan said in a statement.

Next year is likely to be a pivotal one for the video game business: Two new consoles are slated to launch by the holiday season. This year, Microsoft confirmed it will launch the next Xbox, dubbed "Project Scarlett," in 2020.

Here's what we know about the PlayStation 5:

The controller gets a significant upgrade

The PlayStation's classic controller will experience a couple of major changes. First, the "rumble" tech found in current controllers will be replaced by haptic feedback. Ryan said the technology will offer more detailed feedback for players. "Crashing into a wall in a race car feels much different than making a tackle on the football field," Ryan said in a statement. "You can even get a sense for a variety of textures when running through fields of grass or plodding through mud."

The controllers will have adaptive triggers, with inputs that vary based on the action a player performs. As Ryan explained, players might feel things such as the tension of a bow as they draw it back or the acceleration of a vehicle through rocky terrain.

Game downloads will work differently

According to a feature on Wired, players will have more choices in how to download and manage games on the device's solid-state drive. The PS5 could allow players to download only parts of a game, such as the multiplayer portion, Wired reported, or players could download a full game, then delete the single-player campaign when they're done.

What is 'ray tracing'?

The PS5 will include a technique called ray tracing, according to Wired, which will create more robust lighting and sound. Mark Cerny, who helped build the PS5, told Wired accelerated ray tracing is baked into the system itself, instead of being implemented through software.

"Ray tracing’s immediate benefits are largely visual," Wired reported in April. "Because it mimics the way light bounces from object to object in a scene, reflective surfaces and refractions through glass or liquid can be rendered much more accurately, even in real time, leading to heightened realism."

We still don't know what it looks like

What Sony has yet to reveal in this information dump on PS5 is what the console looks like. PlayStation 4, which hit stores in 2013, sported a sleeker body than its bulkier predecessor. If PS5 follows the trajectory of the PS4, expect a first look at the device early next year followed by specific release dates and prices by summer.
